name: Gdansk
fun_fact: Fun fact: Gdansk was the birthplace of the Solidarity movement in 1980 at the Lenin Shipyard under Lech Wa≈Çƒôsa's leadership. This trade union grew to 10 million members (one-third of Poland's working population) and peacefully challenged communist rule, sparking a chain reaction that led to the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the end of the Cold War!

hero_dishes.name: Pierogi
hero_dishes.description: Polish crescent-shaped dumplings made from unleavened dough, boiled or fried, with fillings like potato-cheese (ruskie), meat, sauerkraut-mushroom, or sweet fruit
hero_dishes.origin_story: Dating back to the 13th century in Poland, pierogi have sustained Polish families through centuries. Each region and family has signature fillings and folding techniques passed down through generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pierogarnia Stari Mlyn, Pierogarnia Mandu. Served with fried onions, sour cream (≈õmietana), or crispy bacon bits (skwarki).

hero_dishes.name: Baltic Herring in Sour Cream
hero_dishes.description: Marinated herring fillets in a creamy, tangy sour cream sauce - a Baltic staple
hero_dishes.origin_story: As a major Baltic port in the Hanseatic League, Gdansk's cuisine has always centered on seafood. Herring was abundant, cheap, and could be preserved - essential for long sea voyages and harsh winters.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Targ Rybny (fish market and waterfront dining), traditional milk bars, Baltic seafood restaurants. Often served with dark rye bread and pickles.

hero_dishes.name: Baltic Seafood Platter
hero_dishes.description: Fresh flounder, cod, trout, or perch from the Baltic Sea, often pan-fried or baked with herbs
hero_dishes.origin_story: Gdansk's identity as a port city for over 1,000 years means seafood excellence. The city once had 18 markets, and over 2,000 tonnes of crawfish were sold annually at the city gates during its Hanseatic heyday.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Targ Rybny (premier fish market on Mot≈Çawa River - fresh catches turned into exceptional dishes), Restauracja Gda≈Ñska (Pomeranian regional specialties)

hero_dishes.name: Flaki (Tripe Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Traditional hearty soup made with beef tripe, vegetables, and warming spices, with a unique texture
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish dates to the 14th century in Poland - a warming, economical soup that uses every part of the animal. Perfect for cold Baltic winters and long workdays.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bar Mleczny (milk bars - independent canteens with affordable traditional Polish food), Swojski Smak (celebration of Polish culinary traditions)

hero_dishes.name: ≈ªurek (Sour Rye Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Sour rye soup with white sausage, potatoes, and hard-boiled eggs, often served in a bread bowl
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made with fermented rye flour, this tangy soup is a Polish Easter tradition but enjoyed year-round. The fermentation gives it a distinctive sour kick unlike any other soup.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Swojski Smak (served in traditional bread bowl), Tawerna Dominika≈Ñska, authentic Polish restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Roasted Pork Knuckle
hero_dishes.description: Massive, slow-roasted pork knuckle with crispy skin and tender meat
hero_dishes.origin_story: A hearty sailor's and shipyard worker's meal. The meat falls off the bone after hours of roasting, providing the calories needed for hard physical labor in the cold.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tawerna Dominika≈Ñska (overlooking Mot≈Çawa River), traditional Polish taverns. Often served with bigos (hunter's stew).

signature_drinks.name: Danziger Goldwasser
signature_drinks.description: Herbal liqueur containing tiny flakes of real gold, first produced in Gdansk in 1598 at 40% ABV
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Gdansk's signature spirit. 16th-century alchemists believed the gold had healing properties. Served ice-cold as a digestif after heavy meals. A must-try Gdansk specialty.

signature_drinks.name: ≈ªubr√≥wka (Bison Grass Vodka)
signature_drinks.description: Polish vodka flavored with bison grass from Bia≈Çowie≈ºa Forest, with a distinctive yellow-green tint and subtle herbal flavor
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Often mixed with apple juice ('tatanka' or 'szarlotka' - apple pie shot), or served chilled and neat. Each bottle contains a blade of bison grass.

signature_drinks.name: Polish Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Poland's craft beer revolution has reached Gdansk - try Baltic porter or traditional Polish pilsners
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beer gardens along the waterfront, especially in summer. Gdansk being a port city has a long brewing tradition connected to its Hanseatic past.

food_culture_notes: Gdansk's cuisine is distinct from the rest of Poland due to its port city history and Hanseatic League connections
Bar Mleczny (milk bars) offer authentic, affordable Polish food in no-frills canteens found throughout the city
Gdansk is home to Poland's first Green Michelin Star restaurant - sustainability matters here
The Mot≈Çawa River waterfront is the heart of Gdansk dining - historic granaries converted to restaurants
Fish market tradition remains strong - Targ Rybny is where locals buy fresh Baltic catches
Amber culture intersects with food - amber-honey liqueurs and amber-decorated dining spaces
German, Dutch, and Scandinavian influences from Hanseatic League days still flavor the cuisine
Pierogi are often served as a main course, not just a side dish
